title: NASA James Webb Space Telescope reveals rocky planet formation in harsh environments - The Times of India
summary:
NASA's James Webb Space Telescope Reveals Rocky Planet Formation in Harsh Environments

Published on: December 16, 2023, Source: The Astrophysical Journal

The recent findings from NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope reveal that planets can form and survive in environments that are much harsher than previously believed. This challenges long-held theories about planet formation.

  • James Webb Telescope findings suggest long-lasting planet-forming disks exist around stars with low heavy elements.
  • Planet-forming disks can survive for tens of millions of years, providing ample time for planets to form.
  • Research challenges traditional models that argue planets cannot form in metal-poor environments.
  • Implications extend to understanding planet formation in the early universe, potentially dating back to shortly after the Big Bang.
“This implies that planets could have begun forming at a much earlier stage in the universe’s history than previously thought.” - Guido De Marchi

The discovery revolutionizes our understanding of planet formation and opens new avenues for research in astronomy, particularly regarding the early universe and the origins of our solar system.
newTitle: NASA's James Webb Space Telescope Sheds Light on Planet Formation in Harsh Environments

title: Three asteroids are on their way to Earth - India Today
summary:
Three Asteroids Approaching Earth Soon

Publication Date: November 2024   |   Source: India Today

On December 17, 2024, three asteroids will approach Earth, presenting unique scientific research opportunities. The asteroids include 2022 YO1, 2024 XR6, and 2024 XC17, all deemed non-threatening to the planet.

  • Asteroids 2022 YO1, 2024 XR6, and 2024 XC17 are set for close encounters with Earth.
  • 2022 YO1 will approach within 7,56,604 kilometers and measures 2.6–5.9 meters.
  • 2024 XR6, measuring 12–26 meters, will pass at about 15 million kilometers away.
  • 2024 XC17, measuring 9.1–20 meters, will come within 7.8 million kilometers.
  • All asteroids pose no threat to Earth and will provide research opportunities for astronomers.
Astronomers are tracking the asteroids with advanced systems to study their trajectories, sizes, and compositions, enhancing understanding of near-Earth dynamics.

The upcoming flybys of these asteroids present an excellent opportunity for scientific observation without endangering Earth.

NASA funded commercial space station Starlab meets crucial developmental milestones - News9 LIVE
summary:
NASA's Starlab Space Station Achieves Key Development Milestones

Date: December 2024 | Source: Science News

Starlab is a NASA-funded commercial space station initiative aimed at ensuring the continuity of scientific operations as the International Space Station approaches retirement. The project has successfully met multiple developmental milestones.

  • Starlab has passed reviews for its habitat structural test article, systems design, integrated operations, and structural test plan.
  • The structural test article verifies the design of the space station's habitation module.
  • Proper safety reviews and preliminary design reviews are expected to complete by the end of the year.

Low Earth Orbit Destination

NASA is also partnering with private companies like Axiom Space and Boeing for developing additional commercial low Earth orbit destinations, reinforcing its foothold in microgravity research.
newTitle: NASA's Starlab Space Station Achieves Key Development Milestones

title: Twins were the norm for our ancient primate ancestors — one baby at a time had evolutionary advantages - Down To Earth Magazine
summary:
Twins Were Common for Ancient Primate Ancestors, Study Finds

Date & Source: Publication Date: Not specified, Source: Not specified

Twins have been rare in human history and for that reason can seem special. Many cultures associate twins with health and vitality, while others see them as a philosophical reminder of the duality of life and death, good and evil.

Our recent research suggests that twins were actually the norm much further back in primate evolution, rather than an unusual occurrence worthy of note. Despite the fact that almost all primates today, including people, usually give birth to just one baby, our most recent common ancestor, which roamed North America about 60 million years ago, likely gave birth to twins as the standard.

  1. Twins were the norm for ancient primate ancestors about 60 million years ago.
  2. The switch to singletons occurred early on, at least 50 million years ago, and was advantageous for primates to develop only one fetus per pregnancy.
  3. Having a single offspring allowed for larger bodies and brains, crucial for complex learning.
  4. Rates of twins have almost doubled in the US over the past 50 years due to advances in assistive reproductive technologies.
  5. Having twins today can be dangerous for both the mother and babies, with more than half of all twins in the US being born prematurely.
Our findings don’t mean that having twins today is a disadvantage — although, as a mother of multiples, Tesla can certainly say it’s not easy. But having twins today is quite a different experience from our tiny primate ancestors birthing in the trees 60 million years ago.

Despite these risks, our research shows that twins are a critical part of our genetic history.
newTitle: Twins Were Common for Ancient Primate Ancestors, Study Finds

title: 5 mesmerising star formation images captured by NASA James Webb Space Telescope - HT Tech
summary:
5 Mesmerising Star Formation Images Captured by NASA James Webb Space Telescope

Publication Date: December 17, 2024 | Source: HT TECH

This article presents five stunning images of star formation, beautifully captured by the NASA James Webb Space Telescope, shedding light on the fascinating processes involved in star formation.

  • Star formation can occur through various means such as the collision of different molecular clouds and galaxies.
  • It takes between 10,000 to 100,000 years for a star to reach its fully formed shape.
  • The Hubble and Webb telescopes have unveiled mesmerizing images showcasing young star clusters and star formation regions.
  • Notable regions explored include NGC 602 and NGC 604, which are hotbeds of stellar activity.
  • The Rho Ophiuchi cloud complex is highlighted as the closest star-forming region to Earth.
“These images demonstrate the ongoing processes of star formation and the beauty of the universe.”

This collection of images reminds us of the vastness and complexity of our universe and the exciting discoveries facilitated by advanced space telescopes.
newTitle: 5 Mesmerising Star Formation Images Captured by NASA's James Webb Space Telescope

Jupiter's Hellish Moon Isn't Powered by a Hidden Ocean of Magma, Study Finds - ScienceAlert
summary:
Jupiter's Moon Io Powered by Localized Magma Chambers, Not a Global Ocean

Published on: October 2023, Source: Science Alert

New research indicates that the volcanic activity on Jupiter's moon Io is not driven by a hidden ocean of magma, as previously suggested. Instead, scientists have found that the volcanoes are fed by a network of small magma chambers within a primarily solid mantle.

  • The study used NASA's Juno spacecraft images and gravitational data.
  • It counters previous theories suggesting a global magma ocean under Io’s surface.
  • The findings have implications for understanding planetary formation and evolution.
  • Io's surface is covered with volcanic remnants from its numerous eruptions.
  • This research provides insights into tidal heating processes in celestial bodies.
“This constant flexing creates immense energy, which literally melts portions of Io's interior,” says Scott Bolton, a space physicist involved in the study.

The research highlights the complexity of tidal heating effects and broadens the understanding of volcanic processes on other celestial bodies.
newTitle: Jupiter's Moon Io Powered by Localized Magma Chambers, Not a Global Ocean

title: Is Earth at risk? James Webb Space Telescope discovered many tiny asteroids in the asteroid belt between - The Times of India
summary:
James Webb Space Telescope Detects Numerous Tiny Asteroids Between Mars and Jupiter

Date: October 2023 Source: Space.com

Astronomers using the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) have discovered a large number of tiny asteroids in the asteroid belt between Mars and Jupiter, raising concerns about their potential risk to Earth.

  • Discovery of an unexpectedly high number of tiny asteroids in the asteroid belt.
  • The asteroids are significantly smaller than those that caused the extinction of the dinosaurs but pose a greater risk due to their higher collision frequency with Earth.
  • A new computational method developed by astronomers allows for improved detection of these small asteroids using GPU technology.
  • Among the discoveries, six asteroids have orbits that could potentially intersect with Earth's orbit.
  • The JWST's infrared capabilities enhance the detection of faint and fast-moving asteroids.
  • Future observations using JWST and other advanced telescopes, like the Vera C. Rubin Observatory, will enhance tracking and identification of small asteroids.
“This newfound ability to detect small asteroids ... is a critical step toward improving planetary defense.”

The advancements made by the JWST in detecting small asteroids highlight the growing importance of planetary defense strategies and monitoring potential threats to Earth.
newTitle: James Webb Space Telescope Detects Numerous Tiny Asteroids Between Mars and Jupiter

title: Laser beam casts a shadow in a ruby crystal - physicsworld.com
NASA's Perseverance Rover Completes Its Epic Climb to Crater Rim - ScienceAlert
summary:
NASA's Perseverance Rover Completes Its Epic Climb to Crater Rim

Publication Date: December 12, 2023 Source: Universe Today

NASA's Perseverance rover has successfully reached the top of Jezero Crater's rim, a significant milestone achieved after three and a half months of climbing. This journey enhances the rover's ability to explore a new geological area on Mars.

  • The Perseverance rover climbed 500 vertical meters (1,640 vertical feet) to reach Lookout Hill.
  • The upcoming Northern Rim campaign will see the rover drive 6.4 kilometers (4 miles) to investigate up to four locations for geological samples.
  • Perseverance has completed four prior science campaigns since landing in February 2021, focusing on different aspects of Jezero Crater's geology.
  • Significant geological features and potential ancient life evidence are present in the new targeted area.
"The Northern Rim campaign brings us completely new scientific riches as Perseverance roves into fundamentally new geology." - Ken Farley, Caltech

This achievement is crucial for furthering our understanding of Mars's geology and potential for past life.
newTitle: NASA's Perseverance Rover Completes Its Epic Climb to Crater Rim

title: NASA releases long-term strategy for robotic Mars exploration - SpaceNews
summary:
NASA releases long-term strategy for robotic Mars exploration

Publication Date: December 11, 2023

Source: NASA

The National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) has unveiled a new strategy to enhance robotic exploration of Mars, proposing a series of smaller, science-driven missions to prepare for future human exploration.

  • Nasa's 20-year plan encourages low-cost missions at each launch opportunity.
  • The strategy introduces three key science themes: searching for life, supporting human exploration, and understanding Mars as a dynamic planetary system.
  • Smaller missions are expected to cost between $100 million and $300 million each and will focus on specific scientific questions.
  • The plan emphasizes collaboration with commercial and international partners.
  • Nasa's 2025 budget proposal includes $40 million for Mars robotic exploration technologies.
“We want to do that with lower-cost missions that are science driven and has the capability of providing flexible, rapid response to discoveries.” - Becky McCauley Rench

This strategy is aimed at expanding our understanding of Mars and lays the groundwork for future human missions to the planet, emphasizing scientific inquiry and innovative partnerships.
newTitle: NASA's 20-Year Plan for Robotic Mars Exploration

title: Worms at Chernobyl Appear Mysteriously Unscathed by Radiation - ScienceAlert
summary:
Worms at Chernobyl Appear Mysteriously Unscathed by Radiation

Date: March 2024

Source: Science Alert

Microscopic worms, specifically nematodes, living in the Chernobyl Exclusion Zone are found to have no signs of radiation damage to their genomes, suggesting their resilience to extreme conditions. This research could provide insights into DNA repair mechanisms relevant for human medicine.

  • Nematodes collected from the Chernobyl Exclusion Zone show no genomic damage.
  • The CEZ is heavily contaminated, yet these worms adapt without apparent harm.
  • Research led by Sophia Tintori focuses on understanding the underlying mechanisms of their resilience.
  • The findings may help explain individual susceptibility to cancer and inform medical research.
"Now that we know which strains of O. tipulae are more sensitive or more tolerant to DNA damage, we can use these strains to study why different individuals are more likely than others to suffer the effects of carcinogens," said Tintori.

This study sheds light on the complex interactions between living organisms and extreme environmental conditions, with potential implications for long-term health and disease understanding.
newTitle: Worms at Chernobyl Show Resilience to Radiation Damage

title: NASA Finalizes Strategy for Sustaining Human Presence in Low Earth Orbit - IT News Online
A new method to detect dehydration in plants - MIT News
summary:
A New Method to Detect Dehydration in Plants

Publication Date: October 1, 2023 | Source: Nature Communications

Researchers at the Singapore-MIT Alliance for Research and Technology (SMART) have developed a breakthrough sensor technology that can detect drought stress in plants in real-time, allowing for timely interventions to prevent crop loss.

  • Development of the world's first covalent organic framework (COF) sensors integrated within silk fibroin microneedles for in-planta detection of physiological pH changes.
  • The sensors can detect early signs of drought stress, providing warnings up to 48 hours in advance compared to traditional methods.
  • This technology aims to enhance agricultural practices amidst challenges such as climate change and reduced resources.
  • The integration of COF-based sensors and biomaterials facilitates seamless monitoring of plant health.
  • The findings are published in an open-access paper titled “Chromatic Covalent Organic Frameworks Enabling In-Vivo Chemical Tomography.”
“This type of sensor can be easily attached to the plant and queried with simple instrumentation. It can therefore bring powerful analyses into the hands of farmers and researchers alike.” - Professor Michael Strano

This new sensor technology represents a significant advancement in precision agriculture, potentially optimizing crop production and resilience to drought.
newTitle: A New Method to Detect Dehydration in Plants

title: NASA Finalizes Strategy for Sustaining Human Presence in Low Earth Orbit - StreetInsider.com
NASA Finalizes Strategy for Sustaining Human Presence in Low Earth Orbit - NASA
summary:
NASA Finalizes Strategy for Sustaining Human Presence in Low Earth Orbit

Publication Date: October 2023 | Source: NASA

NASA has released its final goals and objectives to sustain a human presence in low Earth orbit, paving the way for advancements in microgravity science and international collaboration.

  • The strategy outlines 13 goals and 44 objectives for low Earth orbit.
  • It aims to ensure the U.S. leadership in space as the ISS approaches retirement in 2030.
  • Stakeholder engagement included over 1,800 comments and workshops to refine the strategy.
  • The goals span commercial infrastructure, scientific research, and international cooperation.
  • The initiative supports deep space exploration efforts toward missions to the Moon and Mars.
“As we near the retirement of the International Space Station in 2030, these objectives are a pivotal next step in solidifying U.S. leadership in space.” - Pam Melroy, NASA Deputy Administrator

The finalized objectives will help NASA navigate the transition to commercial space stations and maintain continuous human presence, essential for future deep space missions.
newTitle: NASA Finalizes Strategy for Sustaining Human Presence in Low Earth Orbit

title: James Webb Space Telescope witnesses Firefly Sparkle galaxy 'being assembled brick by brick' (image, video) - Space.com
summary:
James Webb Space Telescope witnesses Firefly Sparkle galaxy 'being assembled brick by brick'

Publication Date: Dec. 11 Source: NASA

A newly discovered relic galaxy from the early universe, dubbed the Firefly Sparkle Galaxy, has provided insights into the formation of our Milky Way.

  • The Firefly Sparkle Galaxy appears as a warped arc rich with star clusters.
  • Its mass is similar to that of the young Milky Way at an equivalent developmental stage.
  • NASA's James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) utilized gravitational lensing to uncover this galaxy and two of its companions.
  • Researchers identified 10 distinct star clusters within this galaxy, indicating various stages of star formation.
  • The interactions with its companion galaxies are vital for its growth and evolution.
"I didn’t think it would be possible to resolve a galaxy that existed so early in the universe into so many distinct components..." - Lamiya Mowla

This discovery marks a significant step in understanding galaxy formation, showcasing how gravitational interactions influence the growth of young galaxies.
newTitle: James Webb Space Telescope witnesses Firefly Sparkle galaxy 'being assembled brick by brick'

Discovered: Batch of asteroids between Mars, Jupiter - ummid.com
summary:
Batch of Asteroids Discovered Between Mars and Jupiter

Publication Date: Not Specified Source: Live Science

Astronomers have discovered a vast population of small asteroids in the asteroid belt between Mars and Jupiter using archival images from the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST).

  • The newly discovered asteroids range in size from that of a bus to several stadiums.
  • These asteroids, termed “decametre,” collide with Earth 10,000 times more often than larger asteroids.
  • A total of 138 new decametre asteroids were found, along with eight previously known asteroids.
  • NASA has identified two asteroids, 2024 XY5 and 2024 XB6, passing near Earth on December 16, 2024.
“An asteroid just tens of metres in size exploded over Chelyabinsk, Russia, releasing 30 times more energy than the atomic bomb detonated over Hiroshima.”

Overall, this discovery enhances the understanding and tracking of smaller asteroids that may approach Earth.
newTitle: Batch of Asteroids Discovered Between Mars and Jupiter
